utterances: So Joey, if you'd gone ahead with that idea of selling your kidney in the past, you would have been assessed.
Well, the fact is I wouldn't have been able to because my kidney function was even reduced back then not to my knowledge.
But this kidney disease could have been arrested to the point where I actually still could have had some usable function.
And might not need a transplant today.
Exactly.
Exactly.
And I wonder, have you considered going overseas to buy a kidney?
I could never afford that.
I could never afford that.
I'm, you know, my best hope since I really don't have a familial donor is to wait for some kid to kill himself on a street bike and, you know, harvest the parts.
It's - well…
It's pretty dark, but…
It's pretty dark, yeah.
…that's I'm sure I'm not the only one, you know, struggles with that.
It's difficult, but someone else has to die so that I can live.
Joey, we wish you the best of luck.
Thank you.
Appreciate it.
Here's an e-mail that we got from - this from Ross(ph) in Cincinnati.

One of the university hospitals in Cincinnati has started to reward employees who donate a kidney or bone marrow by giving them extra PTO days - those are paid time off - up to five days for kidney, up to two days for bone marrow.
This seems to me to be getting awfully close to paying for organs.
Dr. Delmonico, is that the top of the slippery slope?
No, I don't see that as the same at all.
It's a non-fungible benefit of sort in which there can be a reward for an individual to be a donor to make certain that they have ample time to recover and return to work.
I don't see that as the issue.
What I see as a concern is that once you introduce cash payments, you have no justification to fix that.
We're in a global market of organs.
People are traveling from one country to another to buy those organs.
Why should there's - on what basis does Dr. Matas assume that people won't be wanting to come to the United States to sell their organs?
If you're in a global market, why should we be restricting those from neighboring countries or from Asia to come to the United States as is now the case?
That Asians are traveling to the Middle East to sell their organs.
And let's give Dr. Matas a chance to answer in 30 seconds.
Well, of course, paid time off is a benefit as is where other states have tax deductions.
And the reason to limit this is because we can provide health care and long-term follow-up if we limit this to a specific country.
If you make a global market, you can't provide health care and long-term follow-up and that's why I am only proposing a very limited, regulated market within this country.
And the debate will continue, no doubt.
Dr. Matas, thanks so much for your time today.
Thank you.
Dr.
Arthur Mathas, professor of surgery; director of the Kidney Transplant Program at the University of Minnesota, with us today from Minnesota Public Radio.
And Dr. Delmonico, thank you for your time.
Thank you as well.
Francis Delmonico, a transplant surgeon at Massachusetts General, with us today from our member station in Boston WBUR.
The Democratic Party is in search of a leader.
Now, often, that means finding the next inspirational figure to run as a presidential nominee.
But in their current state, Democrats are beginning with electing someone to chair the Democratic National Committee, which has seen a fair amount of upheaval over the past year.
Party officials vote in Atlanta.
And NPR's Scott Detrow is there right now.
Scott, good morning.
Morning, David.
So a whole lot of candidates have been running for this job.
We've heard from many of them on this program.
What are the differences between them?
Well, you know, it's hard to tell at times because many of the candidates are just agreeing with each other so much.
Still, a lot of people are viewing this race as a proxy for last year's primary.
You have the grassroots, more liberal and activist wing of the party that backed Bernie Sanders.
Then you have the establishment wing that was with Hillary Clinton and, before that, Barack Obama.
And if you take that view, Minnesota Congressman Keith Ellison is the grassroots candidate.
He did get really early support from Bernie Sanders.
And former Labor Secretary Tom Perez has the backing of Obama allies like Joe Biden and Eric Holder.
So those guys are the two main contenders right now in a seven-person field.
And I think another candidate to keep an eye on who could be a dark horse tomorrow is South Bend, Ind., Mayor Pete Buttigieg.
He's seen as a future leader of the party.
And he's gotten some big endorsements, too - especially Howard Dean, who endorsed him a few days ago.
Except the next joke that comes out of her mouth.
For NPR News, I'm Renata Sago in Orlando.
Do you think that there could be Obama fatigue coming up?
You know, people - politicians are a little bit like rock stars, you know.
They have this incredible charisma, and people kind of fall in love with them, have these political crushes.

As we have gone through this incredibly long primary process, do you think that as we enter the general election that people would just get more excited, or that some of them will begin to just tune out a bit?
Excellent question, there will be some people who go in each direction, I suspect, and the great question will be where the preponderance lies.
Will people decide that he's been something of a one-trick pony and they haven't heard anything new from him?
They've seen the big events, they've seen this small caucus organizing, now what can you do?
What can you do to win in the fall?
What do you do to beat John McCain and the Republican machinery in the media, in terms of their own organizing and fundraising, what do you do to beat them?
Does he have a second act?

And I think there will be people who have never really paid a lot of attention to this process up to now, haven't really learnt much about Barack Obama yet, may still be believing what they're seeing on the internet about him.
And those people are going to learn more and be more attracted.
So there will be some people phasing past him a little bit, and some people just coming in to their first appreciation.
And the question will be how those combined and how it stacks up against McCain and his pluses and minuses.
All right.
Let's talk a little bit about the Obama-Clinton ticket.
So first of all, has her essential concession speech changed the outlook, at all, on whether or not she could be the V.P.?
Ultimately no. Ultimately, that is a decision that he has to make on the basis of what he thinks is best for his presidency, and the campaign to get there.
He has appointed three people who are going to vet candidates and give him a recommendation.
And he wants to give them weeks in which to operate.

But there was a period of time last week, right after the last primary and before her concession speech, in which a tremendous force was building within the body politic of her supporters, essentially demanding that being as how they have tied essentially, and the popular vote, and she was not far behind in pledged delegates, he really had to put her on the ticket, he really had no choice.
And that I think has receded.
Now, what about Bill?
There are some - we talked last week on the show about whether or not Bill Clinton would even be welcomed back into Sylvia's, the big, you know soul food restaurant in Harlem.
He's got his offices in Harlem, of course.
Bill Clinton is an incredible campaigner, and he could be an incredible asset.
But right now there seems to be some bitterness between Bill Clinton and Obama supporters, if not Obama himself.
Do we foresee any way that Bill Clinton will be wooed back into the race for president?
We do.
Because this is the biggest game, this is the big casino, and he is, as you say, a great campaigner and a great player.
He's going to want to be out there pushing, in the end he's going to be out there pushing for the Democratic candidate.
And yes, I think he has experienced some resentment of Barack Obama.
He keeps referring to him as that young man, this young man and so on.
Clearly, Bill Clinton enjoyed being the top dog and he had envisioned a kind of return to power through his wife's election as president.
That's all been interrupted now and he's going to have to sort it out, he's going to have to come to terms with his feelings.
He's have to decide that he wants to get back into Sylvia's.
(Soundbite of laughter)
And at that point he's going to say to himself, there's only one team I can be playing on this fall, and he'll get out there and he'll do the best.
As is Hillary, even if she isn't on the ticket, and by the way one reason she might not be on the ticket would be because of the difficulty of dealing with Bill.
All right, let's get to a little practicality before we wrap this up.
Money.
In many races, in many presidential races, the Republicans have had more in the kitty, either for the party or for the candidate.
What are we seeing this time around?
Usually we see the two parties do equally well among the very wealthy who can give the maximum.
But then the Republicans do better among upper-middle-class and middle-class people who are willing to give smaller amounts but give them regularly.
The Democrats, generally speaking, don't do that well with those smaller donors.
That's all changed now because of that dynamic I mentioned earlier.

With a million and a half people out there who have not maxed out, who can give again and give again and many more people who could be at it, some people think he'll have three million contributors by November.

And that means that even if they are given on average a rather small amount of money, it's going to be an enormous war chest, the likes of which neither party has ever seen for a non-incumbent presidential candidate, and which the Democrats have never seen for a president or a non-incumbent candidate.

So this is just going to change that whole kind of logic that we've had in the past, and I think in the end Barack Obama will refuse public financing and say, I've got my own system that's just as public and just as little-guy oriented.
Very quickly, what about feet on the street, grass roots mobilizers, Democrats or Republicans ahead?
Democrats, I think this time because of the enormous enthusiasm Democrats feel in general about this election cycle.

The Republican brand is down, the enthusiasm level is not great and the hard right conservatives don't really like John McCain that much, and so they, and some of the social conservatives who provide a lot of those feet on the ground are not going to be as involved.
Well Ron, it's always great to have you on.
Thanks so much.
My pleasure, Farai.
Ron Elving is the senior Washington editor for NPR and he spoke with us from our headquarters in Washington, D.C.
Before Hurricane Maria, Puerto Rico is on the cusp of an agricultural renaissance.
Local farms were a bright spot in the island's struggling economy, offering more produce, milk and coffee than ever before.
But since the storm, about 80 percent of the crop value on the island has now been destroyed.
For more, we're joined by Ricardo Fernandez in San Juan.
He's president of Puerto Rico Farm Credit.
They offer loans to farmers all over the island.
Welcome to the program.
Hi.
So you've been traveling, I understand it, all over the island checking in on farms.
